utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh there is what we called %uh Teochew Porridge.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So it is rice porridge and there are sort of variety of dishes like steam fish, fried fish %uh salted egg, vegetables- different vegetables cooked in different ways, tofu.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So you pick what you want and you eat it.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh so it depends on what you pick fish, %uh a whole fish of course is more expensive if you are just taking a slice is less And if your taking vegetables usually it's a dollar or seventy cents a little plate.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So because it's so cheap you can take a variety and the three of you can share.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: And so this is like close to where I'm gonna stay if ever?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yes very close you can walk there.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And you can even eat there every day you will not run out of stalls okay because  have so many stalls there %uh I think over a hundred.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: I see.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Yah I was just looking at the picture and I can see that I could probably you know- I couldn't count the stalls there it's probably a very long lane of stalls right?

utterances.transcript: But those are- you- mostly Chinese food, nothing-

utterances.transcript: Yes.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh there is- there are also Indian stalls selling something like %uh %uh fried pancake.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You know prata, it is a dough that is fried and we take it with chicken curry or fish curry or mutton curry.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: %Um, but I'm not really a fan of curry.

utterances.transcript: %Uh that- There probably is but I cannot recall for sure.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Usually- I think yes there is a Thai there is what she call herself Japanese but you know it's the cheaper type of Japanese food there.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So it's at the lower end.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Maybe you pay five dollars for rice and %um %uh piece of meat a sizeable piece of meat on your rice.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And for Thai food you will get your usual green mango, you know.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh the sour and sweet mango %uh and the pad thai, you know pad thai?

utterances.transcript: No I don't.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: the noodles, it's very nice, it's a very special Thai dish.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And %uh even if you don't go to this market %uh you can walk along the streets in Chinatown and you will be able to find Thai food, you'll be able to find %um Malay food %uh even our Muslim restaurant.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So if you want to try different cuisines just outside your hotel you can find.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Wow.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: You have like-

utterances.transcript: We also have a food street there, it's called Smith Street.

utterances.transcript: You can take this down S M I T H Street it's the food street of Singapore.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Smith Street, okay.

utterances.transcript: And what about the prices of the food there?

utterances.transcript: Do you go there a lot too?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yes I go there when I'm in Chinatown I will always eat in Chinatown.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: But because my place is quite near to Chinatown %uh you know I've been- I eat quite often, Maxwell Market especially.

utterances.transcript: So can you see the pictures here?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh okay this one shows the food.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Okay just wait a while for it to load the picture.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You see at night the road is closed off to traffic and the stalls are put out and the stall holders man their cooking just next to the tables

utterances.transcript: %Oh so it's just like a night market of some sort.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yes, but this is for food.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: For food, yah.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And in Chinatown the night market is also a day market.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: %Oh I see.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: There.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So on the next road to this is where they sell things that you can buy like souvenirs.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: This is Smith Street where you eat.

utterances.transcript: %Uh if you walk and you stop and look at shops maybe ten minutes otherwise I- if you walk fast I think five minutes you can get there.

utterances.transcript: Alright, that sounds good.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So you can get your souvenirs, cheap souvenirs %uh if you need to buy like for twenty people or thirty people you don't want to spend a fortune.

utterances.speaker: Guide

utterances.transcript: Yes, but %uh there would be things like you know chopsticks with %uh-

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: It is %uh a little stalls where they sell %uh souvenirs like during the new year they sell we~ decorations for Chinese New Year.

utterances.transcript: %Ah okay.

utterances.transcript: You want- okay you want pictures of the shops let me see if I can get it for you?

utterances.transcript: So how long have you been doing this Jeanne?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: I've been doing it for more than twenty years.

utterances.transcript: %Oh my goodness so you really must love it, right?

utterances.transcript: Yes.

utterances.transcript: I don't want to ask why.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh they are- you know that we spruced up Chinatown that's why if you're worried about anything all the buildings are very clean, they have been conserved so they look %uh new but in fact they are from the eighteen hundreds.

utterances.transcript: Wow.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yah.

utterances.transcript: Can you see the picture of the stalls there?

utterances.transcript: So here you see the lanterns decorating the street side for the lunar new year which is around February.

utterances.transcript: And then it's quite crowded.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Could-

utterances.transcript: But at this time that you %uh you can also buy things along Chinatown but you won't have to jostle with people it will be more comfortable for you.

utterances.speaker: Guide

utterances.transcript: You-

utterances.transcript: Food street market.

utterances.transcript: Okay.

utterances.transcript: %Uh here you can see some %uh I don't know if you're interested in these, Chinese %uh artefacts.

utterances.transcript: Yah.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: They're actually nice in the home and they say that they bring I don't know luck or something.

utterances.transcript: Very colour~ Ye~ Yes.

utterances.transcript: %Uh they- during the Chinese New Year period before the Chinese New Year we get a lot of shop selling these decorations.

utterances.transcript: I could just imagine.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: %Uh yes.

utterances.transcript: %Hm that's nice.

utterances.transcript: What are those things hanging there in the middle of the picture?

utterances.transcript: This- the brown things?

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Yup.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: If I'm not mistaken this is a dried gourd, G O U R D. It is a fruit like a melon that is dried up and when it's dried it hardens and they dig out the centre.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And when it's thoroughly dried it is a container, it's waterproof.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So in in China they are used to keep Chinese medicines even liquidised medicines inside these containers.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So when you give this away to somebody it is %uh a symbol of wishing him good health and longevity.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: So new year you can get them- %uh usually you'll give them to the older people.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: It's symbolic, nobody would put medicine in them now we just buy it for fun.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: Wow.

utterances.speaker: Tourist
utterances.transcript: But of course it's available even if it's not the new year, correct?

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: No it's available all the time.

utterances.transcript: %Uh here we have something fancy, we have the fans.

utterances.transcript: Okay these are the chops- these are the fans.

utterances.transcript: And hand painted, no not really?

utterances.transcript: %Uh I think it's printed.

utterances.transcript: I better get one of that.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: You can bar~ that man is nice you can bargain with him.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: He did it for school kids at %uh you know a few dollars just to amuse them.

utterances.transcript: Yah.

utterances.transcript: I have some myself.

utterances.transcript: %Uh this is a skill from the Chinese %uh are very good at.

utterances.speaker: Guide

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: And after they finish cutting they open up the paper and you've got this wonderful design %uh-

utterances.transcript: Okay.

utterances.transcript: That's interesting.

utterances.transcript: Okay.

utterances.transcript: We actually have %um chopsticks at home and when I was little just for fun my brother and I would usually use chopsticks for eating just for the fun of it but it's been a while since I actually use one.

utterances.transcript: It looks delicious.

utterances.transcript: Okay, you're talking about the fish?

utterances.speaker: Guide

utterances.transcript: They believe that it can cure them of %um sickness and things like that.

utterances.speaker: Guide
utterances.transcript: Yah.

utterances.transcript: Okay.
